review.title: Textual Paralanguage and its Implications for Marketing Communications
review.abstract: Both face-to-face communication and communication in online environments convey information beyond the actual verbal message. In a traditional face-to-face conversation, paralanguage, or the ancillary meaning- and emotion-laden aspects of speech that are not actual verbal prose, gives contextual information that allows interactors to more appropriately understand the message being conveyed. In this paper, we conceptualize textual paralanguage (TPL), which we define as written manifestations of nonverbal audible, tactile, and visual elements that supplement or replace written language and that can be expressed through words, symbols, images, punctuation, demarcations, or any combination of these elements. We develop a typology of textual paralanguage using data from Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram. We present a conceptual framework of antecedents and consequences of brands' use of textual paralanguage. Implications for theory and practice are discussed.
histories: Forthcoming in the Journal of Consumer Psychology
review.COMMENTS: Forthcoming in the Journal of Consumer Psychology

metadata.title: Textual Paralanguage and Its Implications for Marketing Communications

sections.heading: Auditory Nonverbal Communication
sections.text: One of the earliest theorists to deal with non-verbal communication was Trager (1958, 1960), who noted the depth and importance of information conveyed through linguistic aspects such as pitch, rhythm, and tempo. Trager (1958) described the parallelism of vocal qualities and vocalizations that qualify literal words. These vocal qualities are called the "implicit" three aspects of language (Mehrabian, 1970), since human language is inherently permeated by vocal tones. Communicating aspects of language alongside literal words has been common among playwrights for centuries. In cinema and theater, paralinguistic elements are inserted into scriptions to give directions, convey emotions, and facilitate interaction, guiding theatrical performance across languages, cultures, and time (Poyatos, 2008).

sections.heading: Visual Nonverbal Communication
sections.text: Just as auditory aspects of the language of face-to-face communication are inherent, so are visual elements of communication. Birdwhistell (1970) examined kinesics, the conscious or unconscious body movements that possess communicative value, including human gestures and body language. An important physical communicator is the human face; some scholars claim that it is the primary source of communicative information alongside human language (Knapp et al., 2013). Subtle changes in facial muscle movements can communicate emotional states and provide nonverbal feedback (Ekman et al., 1987). Unsurprisingly, visual textual parallel linguistic elements exist in the form of facial emojisms. Nonverbal visual elements are not exclusively associated with physical movements. Visual style conveys information in direct communication through embellishment, clothing, style, tattoos, and cosmetics (Barnard et al, 2001).

sections.heading: Sample
sections.text: To adequately capture the phenomenon of TPL, we selected major national brands that have a diverse social media presence. It is common practice for brand communications to come from both a corporate account (e.g. @ Geico) and a speaker account (e.g. @ TheGEICOGecko, 2014), and for each brand and speaker the most recent posts from Twitter, Facebook and Instagram were collected. These text-based messages were then imported into the TAMS Analyzer, an open source text coding tool, and three people manually encoded the tweets for the TPL. (For more methodological information and analysis, see the attached methodological details.)

sections.heading: Results
sections.text: In our example, 20.6% of brand tweets, 19.1% of Facebook posts, and 31.3% of Instagram posts contain TPL. Across the three platforms, there is evidence that all five types of TPL are used by brands, with personality traits appearing most frequently and least frequently (Tables 1, 2, 3, and 4).Uses of TPL arose from data that was not originally theorized by our review of literature, one example being the letter name of words. sections.heading: Account
sections.text: Methodological Details Appendix This appendix provides further details on the exploratory study reported in the script. To ensure the saturation of the TPL phenomenon, we have collected data from consumers and brands. We describe the analyses we have conducted on consumer tweets, brand tweets, brand replies, brand posts on Facebook and brand posts on Instagram.

sections.heading: Consumer Tweets
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: To obtain a sample of public tweets, a Python program was written to collect tweets from
sections.text: Twitter for analysis. Twitter is an ideal social media platform for studying TPL, as posts are primarily textual, messages are limited to 140 characters, and programmatic access to all public tweets is possible via an Application Programming Interface (API). To get a sample of all public tweets in English, the program queried Twitter streaming with the parameter "language = en" at different times of the day (during the day in the United States) over several days, up to 5,000 tweets were purchased. This sample provides consumer-level data on how individuals TPL. After each query, tweets were downloaded in JSON format and stored using UTF-8encoding to preserve emojis and other symbols. Tweets were then imported into the TAMS Analyzer, an open source research tool for manually encoding text paralanguage (see Table A1 for the code guide).

sections.heading: Brand Tweets
sections.text: Twitter is used not only by consumers, but also by brands (King, 2008).The APython program was written to collect brand tweets for analysis.For each brand, the program queried the Twitter REST API, downloaded the tweets in JSON format, and saved the tweets using UTF-8 encoding to preserve emojis and other symbols.All at responses (tweets starting with "@") were excluded from this sample, since they are primarily replies to tweets from other Twitter users; furthermore, At responses are typically only seen by the intended recipient of the tweet. However, for clarity, we analyze the at responses in the following section. Retweets were also excluded because the text of a retweet is not composed by the brand. The most recent 200 tweets for each brand were imported into the TAMS Analyzer for coding; only three of the brand accounts had less than 200 tweets after removal of retweets and replies were resolved by researchers ($4 = appino N). (= $4)

sections.heading: Of the 4,168 brand tweets that were analyzed, 859 (20.6%) contained one or more
sections.text: In total, there were 1,233 cases of TPL use, of which 55.6% were language qualities, 12.7% vocalizations, 0.6% tactile kinesics, 14.4% visual kinesics and 16.7% artifacts.

sections.heading: Brand At-Replies
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A Python program was written to collect brand at-replies for analysis. For each brand, the
sections.text: The program queried the Twitter REST API, downloaded the at responses in JSON format, and saved the at responses using UTF-8 encoding to preserve emojis and other symbols; the last 150 at responses for each brand were imported into TAMS Analyzer to encode them; only five brand accounts had fewer than 150 at responses: aflac (N = 29), forestry service (N = 7), fritolay (N = 149), realtonytiger (N = 125), and woodyowl (N = 83); the at responses were encoded independently of four coders, and the resulting documents were compared with a kaleidoscope; discrepancies were resolved by discussion among researchers; of the 2,943 at responses from the brand, 1,025 (34.8%) contained one or more cases of TPL (see Table A2).

sections.heading: Brand Facebook Posts
sections.text: The posts on the Facebook pages were downloaded using DiscoverText, a cloud-based text analysis service. = 36. After filtering the posts on the Facebook pages by brand, the last 250 brand posts were downloaded and imported into the TAMS Analyzer to encode them. Only one brand had fewer than 250 posts: cheerios (N = 249). Facebook posts were encoded independently by four encoders, and the resulting documents were compared with Kaleidoscope. Discrepancies were resolved by discussions among the researchers. Of the 3,749 brand Facebook posts analyzed, 716 (19.1%) contained one or more instances of TPL (see Table 2 in the manuscript). Overall, there were 933 instances of TPL use, of which 63.5% were artistic qualities, 8.9% vocalizations, 0.2% tactile kinesics, 18.9% visual kinesics, and 8.6% artificial kinesics.

sections.heading: Table A1: Textual Paralanguage Coding Guide
sections.text: Voice Quality ("VQ") Indicates how the word (s) should be spoken • Emphasis: really??!?!!! Awesome!!! • Stress: They are the BEST • Pitch: I rEAlly want that • Rhythm: Best. Day. • Any. or p l e • Tempo: So loooooong or I guess that..... or • Scare quotes: That was "fun." • Silence: [empty messages] • Intensity or volume: * whisper * • Intonation: [often communicated by misspellings; e.g., "vell vell vell vell vell"] • Censorship: # $% ^ • Spelling: M-i-n-eVocalization ("VS") Fillers, meaningful expressions or bodily sounds (not necessarily a "word") that BRyew • haha, hehe • drumroll • umm • lmao • lmao • uh • uh • laughs • nich • nich • • nich • nich • • nich • nich • nich • • nich • nich • • nich • nich • • nich • niche • • niche • • niche • • • niche • • niche • • niche • • niche • • niche • • niche • • niche • • niche • niche • • • niche • niche • • niche • niche • • niche • niche • niche • • niche • niche • niche • niche • niche • niche • • niche • niche • • niche • niche • • niche • • niche • niche • niche • • niche • niche • niche • • niche • niche • • • niche • niche • niche • niche • niche.

sections.heading: Additional notes on TPL coding:
sections.text: • If... "" is used exclusively to separate tweet content and linkage, do not encode as TPL. • If... "" is at the end of the tweet because the author has run out of characters, do not encode as TPL. • A single exclamation point ("!") should not be encoded as it is regular punctuation. • A retweet of spam is still encoded as spam, but a retweet of a bot should be encoded as a rectangular tweet, as it is no longer automated (someone actually retweets these thoughts / ideas / actions / sounds). • If the same emoji is repeated, it is encoded as an element: {A} {/ A} {/ A}}. • If different emojis are strung together, they are encoded separately: {VK} {/ VK} {VK} {/ VK} {A} {/ A} {A} {A} If both types of VQ are {Q / K, both types of TQ are in one word.

Uses of TPL emerged from the data that were not initially theorized from our review of the literature. One example is the spelling out of words. In a Facebook post, Chester the Cheetah (2014) wrote, “How do you spell Flamin’ Hot CHEETOS Burrito? M-I-N-E”.

Successful interaction with customers online has been attributed to whether or not an organization can demonstrate a “conversational human voice” (Kelleher, 2009).
Since nonverbal cues are lacking in electronic communication (Walther, 1993), online communicators use TPL to convey meaning and emotion.

Nonverbal communication may be processed by either hemisphere of the brain, although the left hemisphere is thought to process more of the verbal and linguistic aspects of communication, and the right hemisphere is credited with visual/spatial relationships, Gestalt information, and the bulk of nonverbal information (Knapp et al., 2013).

When a consumer is reading a message that contains TPL, does she unconsciously simulate or mimic the expression? For instance, when encountering “*shrug*”, do people physically shrug their shoulders? There is research to suggest that when reading auditory cues, people sound out words or imitate how they believe the words to be communicated (Ehri, 2005).

Language, as the basis for human interaction (Grice, 1975), has the capacity to reveal our social and psychological selves.

metadata.abstractText: Both face-to-face communication and communication in online environments convey information beyond the actual verbal message. In a traditional face-to-face conversation, paralanguage, or the ancillary meaningand emotion-laden aspects of speech that are not actual verbal prose, gives contextual information that allows interactors to more appropriately understand the message being conveyed. In this paper, we conceptualize textual paralanguage (TPL), which we define as written manifestations of nonverbal audible, tactile, and visual elements that supplement or replace written language and that can be expressed through words, symbols, images, punctuation, demarcations, or any combination of these elements. We develop a typology of textual paralanguage using data from Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram. We present a conceptual framework of antecedents and consequences of brands’ use of textual paralanguage. Implications for theory and practice are discussed. A customer of Whole Foods tweets that he received a bad cupcake from the grocer, to which Whole Foods replies, “A bad cupcake?!!?! Oh No!!! I’m so sorry. *sigh* Thank you for letting us know” (Whole Foods Market, 2013). How does communication on social media affect brand perceptions? Marketers are communicating with customers using a “shorthand, digital language” (Smith, 2015), yet the nature of these communications is under-investigated. In marketing, research on linguistics has focused primarily on the effects of word choice, such as the effect of explanatory words on consumption experiences (Moore, 2012), refusal words on choice (Patrick & Hagtvedt, 2012), and vowel sounds in brand names on brand preferences (Lowrey & Shrum, 2007). We also see evidence that imperative messages (e.g., “Buy Now!”) are more effective in uncommitted consumer-brand relationships (Moore, ZemackRugar, & Fitzsimons, working paper), and assertive statements are more effective at garnering consumer compliance for hedonic products (Kronrod, Grinstein, & Wathieu, 2012). In contrast, our work focuses not on the words said, but on the way nonverbal information is conveyed in writing. As computer-mediated communication (CMC) has become more prevalent, people have evolved new ways of communicating. Electronic messages are often imbued with nonverbal cues that signal individual characteristics, attitudes, and emotions. Indeed, various researchers recognize that people adapt to the limitations of CMC by creating surrogates for missing social cues (Byron & Baldridge, 2007; Ganster, Eimler, & Krämer, 2012; Walther, 1996). The primary goal of this paper is to provide a framework for the surrogates that people are using in digital communications. We define textual paralanguage (TPL) as written manifestations of nonverbal audible, tactile, and visual elements that supplement or replace written language and that can be
